I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

1. 
I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed policy-
based loan to the Islamic Republic of Pakistan for subprogram 2 of the Public Sector Enterprises 
Reform Program.1 
 
2. 
The  proposed  subprogram  2  of  the  Public  Sector  Enterprises  Reform  Program 
(programmatic  approach)  will  help  the  Government  of  Pakistan  achieve  and  sustain  reform 
initiatives aimed at enhancing the performance of public sector enterprises (PSEs) by improving 
their  corporate  governance  and  accountability,  and  reducing  their  contingent  liabilities. 
Subprogram 2 will facilitate the creation of fiscal space for critical development expenditures.2  
 

II. 

THE PROGRAM 

A. 

Rationale 

Finances  of  PSEs  remain  weak  despite  recent  reform  initiatives.  The  183  PSEs 
3. 
owned by the government comprise 169 public sector companies (PSCs), 7 development finance 
institutions, and 7 federal authorities. These federal PSEs employ more than 402,543 workers, 
with  total  assets  of  PRs10,823  billion  ($103  billion)  in  FY2015.  In  FY2015,  172  PSEs  (94%) 
disclosed  their  financial  statements,  with  53  PSEs  (29%)  reporting  losses  despite  significant 
budget  transfers.  Total  reported  aggregate  profit  was  PRs72.98  billion  ($0.7  billion),  with  total 
reported loss of PRs20.35 billion ($0.2 billion). The government’s fiscal risk exposure (combining 
loans and guarantees) was PRs1,472 billion ($14.05 billion) in FY2015.3 Despite recent reform 
initiatives,  PSEs  continue  to  rely  on  significant  regular  fiscal  transfers  and  sovereign  credit 
guarantees  to  maintain  their  operations.  The  power  distribution  companies  (DISCOs)  are  the 
major  recipient  of  such  transfers.  Other  important  beneficiaries  include  Pakistan  International 
Airlines, Pakistan Steel Mill, and Pakistan Railways. In FY2016, the budget allocation to support 
PSEs’ daily operations, including subsidies and other transfers, constituted 59% of overall budget 
allocations to the PSEs. This severely limits the critical capital development expenditures needed 
to improve the efficiency of PSEs. 
 
Fiscal transfers to PSEs jeopardize fiscal sustainability and impede government’s 
4. 
development  expenditure.  High  levels  of  fiscal  transfers  to  PSEs  undermine  overall  fiscal 
stability  and  growth,  which  adversely  affects  critical  investment  on  social  and  economic 
infrastructure, especially when the government has very limited ability to fund such investment 
through borrowings. The government recognizes the importance of reducing the fiscal deficit and 
government borrowings, and imposed severe cuts in budget transfers to PSEs starting in FY2014; 
transfers declined from 3.2% of gross domestic product (GDP) in FY2012 to 1.5% in FY2016,4 
and 0.5% in the first 8 months of FY2017 (Figure 1).5 This budget constraint can help boost the 
accountability  and  efficiency  of  PSEs.  Acknowledging  the  fact  that  reduction  in  budgetary 
transfers  is  partially  attributable  to  improved  performance  of  some  PSEs  (including  Pakistan 
Railways),  hard  budget  constraint  could  adversely  affect  the  government’s  ability  to  invest  in

Government’s PSE reform initiatives, sustainability, and constituency building for 
5. 
reforms.  In mid-FY2013  the government  embarked  on  a  PSE  reform  program to restore  PSE 
financial viability and reduce fiscal transfers,7 but soon recognized that a successful PSE reform 
program requires that two prerequisites be met. First, vested stakeholder interests, particularly 
those of PSE employees, require improvements in the operating environment and governance of 
PSEs  prior  to  privatization.  Adequate  stakeholder  consultations  and  a  gradual  approach  are 
necessary to secure the support of stakeholders for such reforms, which is also true for structural 
reforms that address human resource issues and the affordability of user charges of many PSEs, 
including DISCOs and Pakistan Railways. Second, many reforms require that reform initiatives 
be maintained over a long period to produce the desired results.8 
 
6.

initiatives,  ADB  approved  subprogram  1  of  the  programmatic  approach  in  June  2016. 9 
Subprogram  2  continues  reforms  initiated  under  subprogram  1.  The  programmatic  approach 
addresses the following three important challenges the government faces while initiating critical 
PSE reforms:

Continued assistance for these reforms would consolidate and sustain gains made 
to improve PSE performance. 
The need to plan for and address the substantial adjustment costs associated with 
implementation  of  PSE  reforms.  These  costs  are  a  major  challenge,  given 
Pakistan’s  current fiscal context. Identification  of reforms  and selection  of  PSEs 
will need to be done very carefully, given the government’s priorities. 

 
Need  for  sequencing  of  reforms.  Subprogram  2  is  part  of  an  integrated  solution 
7. 
comprising policy-based loans under a programmatic approach, with clear program costs. This 
will  help  ADB  and  the  government  design  and  implement  policy  actions  supporting  the 
government’s reform  agenda  without  excessively  straining the government’s  budget to finance 
the cost of reforms. Several policy actions are politically sensitive and will require time to prepare, 
including building a constituency for reforms.11 It is critical that reforms are properly identified and 
logically sequenced over two subprograms, under the programmatic approach, if they are to be 
effectively  implemented.  Some  policy  actions  serve  to  support  other  actions  included  in  the 
programmatic  approach  (e.g.,  a  public  awareness  campaign),  requiring  that  the  various  policy 
actions under the overall programmatic approach be carefully timed.  
 
8. 
Development  coordination.  The  programmatic  approach  is  part  of  a  well-coordinated 
multidonors  package  for  PSE  reforms  in  Pakistan.  The  International  Monetary  Fund  (IMF) 
approved a 3-year extended arrangement under the Extended Fund Facility in September 2013,12 
which concluded in 2016. The World Bank approved four development policy credits in April 2014, 
May  2015,  June  2016,  and  in  March  2017.  These  two  programs  also  support  some  reforms 
(including privatization) relevant for PSEs in Pakistan. Subprogram 2 complements and carries 
forward similar reforms, especially in the areas of implementing corporate governance rules and 
privatization.

public sector enterprises improved. In line with the Public Sector Companies

Development Financing Needs 

D. 

16. 
As  an  integral  part  of  the  ongoing  fiscal  consolidation  initiatives—which  encompass 
maintaining a moderate debt-to-GDP ratio and building fiscal buffers against adverse shocks—
the government plans to lower the budget deficit (excluding grants) to 4.2% of GDP in FY2017 
from  5.4%  in  FY2015,  mainly  through  revenue  mobilization  and  expenditure  rationalization. 
However, given the sluggish nature of revenue improvements over the short to medium term, the 
burden  of  fiscal  consolidation  will  primarily  fall  on  expenditure  rationalization,  especially 
development expenditures. As a result, it will be difficult to maintain, if not augment, the past trend 
of  development  expenditures  and  development  loans  (primarily  for  investment  to  augment 
capacity)  for  PSEs  (including  Pakistan  Railways).  This  is  a  clear  illustration  of  a  hard  budget 
constraint and its impact on development financing, given the rigidity in nondiscretionary recurrent 
expenditures  (salary,  pensions,  and  interest).  The  government’s  support  for  productive 
investments in PSEs needs to be revived, and will be supported under the program. 
 
17. 
It will also be difficult for the government to incur additional costs to carry out PSE reforms, 
unless  expenditures  on  specific  items  are  targeted  and  partly  financed  by  the  government’s 
development  partners.  Strong  expenditure  rationalization  efforts  will  be  needed  to  enable 
additional  reform-related  expenditures,  to  the  extent  these  are  reflected  in  the  federal  budget, 
within the stipulated fiscal deficit targets. 
 
18. 
 Unfunded pension liability is a risk to a company's financial condition due to underfunding 
of  defined  benefit  pension  plan.  Unfunded  pensions  and  other  retirement  benefits  are  major 
constraints  for  timely  privatization  (or  strategic  sale  of  shares)  of  DISCOs.  Unless  addressed 
efficiently,  these  will  have  an  adverse  impact  on  the  government’s  divestment  income  from 
privatization.  Therefore,  it  is  proposed  that  the  government  will  help  creating  Retirement  Cost 
Funds and encourage operationalization of these Funds.  Putting some of these items together 
and combining them with the government’s commitment to reduce the fiscal deficit-to-GDP ratio, 
development financing needs of approximately $897 million over the entire program period (2016–
2018)  is  foreseen. 34 The  programmatic  approach  is  expected  to  finance  nearly  67%  of  this 
development financing requirement. Thus, the programmatic approach will help the government 
to pursue, without breaching the fiscal targets, its macroeconomic reform agenda, including PSE 
reforms.  
 
19. 
 The government has requested a concessional loan of $300 million from ADB’s ordinary 
capital resources to help finance subprogram 2. The loan will have a 25-year term, including a 
grace period of 5 years; an interest rate of 2% per year during the grace period and thereafter; 
and such other terms and conditions set forth in the draft loan agreement.

The  beneficiaries  will  primarily  be  the  domestic, industrial,  agricultural,  and  commercial

clients of public goods and services provided by PSEs, which will deliver improved services in a

A. 

Economic 

The beneficiaries of subprogram 2 will be the people of Pakistan, who will directly benefit 
24. 
from  the  improved  delivery  of  services,  especially  in  the  areas  of  power  and  transportation. 
Moreover,  subprogram  2  will  facilitate  government  fiscal  investments  in  social  and  economic 
infrastructure,  which  will  result  in  improved  health  and  education  services  and  economic 
opportunities. In addition, subprogram 2 will stimulate private sector activity by partly substituting 
government service commitments. The beneficial effect on federal finances will originate primarily 
from  three  sources:  non-debt  capital  receipts (disinvestment  income),  reduced fiscal  transfers, 
and higher dividend income. In addition, the government will reduce its contingent liabilities once 
pensions and related retirement liabilities are funded appropriately.36

Poverty and Social 

C. 

Subprogram 2 has a positive impact on poverty reduction and social issues, through two 
28. 
interlinked  mechanisms.  First,  support  for  augmenting  and  sustaining  the  government’s 
development  financing  will  substantially  impact  human  and  income  poverty.  Second,  many 
reforms  will  help  the  government  reduce  the  economic  and  fiscal  costs  that  Pakistan’s  PSEs 
impose  on  consumers,  taxpayers,  and  beneficiaries  of  social  services.  Subprogram  2  will 
maximize the benefits that private management and improved corporate and sector governance 
can  bring  to  the  economic  efficiency  and  financial  feasibility  of  PSEs.  These  changes  are 
expected  to  improve  access  to  basic  services  such  as  electricity  (through  power  distribution 
companies)  and  public  transportation  (through  railways).  The  PSEs  to  be  restructured  and 
privatized  may  decrease  their  demand  for  low-skilled  labor  in  the  future.  The  programmatic 
approach will therefore facilitate critical initiatives, through the targeted policy actions, to address 
labor issues, particularly related to retirement benefits and alternative skills development.37 The 
reform  measures  under  subprogram  2  will  in  turn  help  free  government  fiscal  resources, 
facilitating  higher  public  spending  on  social  sectors,  particularly  health,  education,  and  social 
protection.  Subprogram  2  has  important  gender  impacts.  Policy  measures  will  support  gender 
inclusiveness  by  ensuring  mandatory  representation  of  women  on  PSE  boards,  and  mandate 
regular reporting of gender statistics of PSE boards.38 The mandatory presence of at least one 
female member on each PSE board under the approved change in the Companies Bill 2017 will 
increase women’s representation to at least 15% from the current low level of 4% (commercial 
PSCs) and 3% (noncommercial PSCs).
